Award.AwardTitle: Simultaneous Integration of Combinatorial Histone Marks by the Atypical PHD-finger Protein EDM2 in Arabidopsis Thaliana

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
While the role of DNA in life processes is generally limited to the storage of genetic information, proteins have many structural roles and control nearly all biochemical processes in cells. Eukaryotic cells contain certain types of proteins, termed histones, which physically associate with DNA. Originally histones were found to be critical for the organized compaction of DNA that enables the DNA to fit into the nuclei of eukaryotic cells and to be faithfully transmitted (after duplication) to each of both daughter cells after cell divisions. During the past decade, a new type of biological code critical for the proper function of genes has emerged. This so-called histone or epigenetic code is manifested in certain chemical modifications of DNA and DNA-associated histone proteins. In contrast to the DNA code, which provides instructions for the synthesis of proteins, the histone code defines the activity states of genes and determines to what extent their genetic information is utilized. Numerous types of chemical modifications that can mark histone proteins at defined positions within their amino acid sequences have been identified. In some cases defined histone marks have been associated with enhanced or suppressed activity of genes. For example, the addition of an acetyl-tag to the 4th amino acid (a lysine) of the histone type H3 is often found in highly active genes, while methyl-tags at amino acid 9 (also a lysine) of H3 has been associated with suppressed genetic activity. It is also well established that certain proteins can ?read? this histone code and bind to these defined marks. When recruited to defined DNA regions by docking to their cognate histone marks, such histone binding proteins can alter activity levels of their respective target genes.

Intellectual Merit-
This project focuses on the characterization of a new type of histone binding protein in Arabidopsis plants. The EDM2 protein, which was originally identified as a critical regulator of plant immune responses, was found by the PI?s laboratory to specifically bind to the histone H3 protein bearing certain combinations of three different chemical marks. Responsible for this unusual property is a part of EDM2 related to the known-PHD finger domain. While conventional PHD-finger domains have been found previously to dock to either single or double histone marks, it is remarkable that the atypical PHD-finger domain of EDM2 appears to be unable to bind to single or double marks, but is only able to ?read? triple histone modifications. This novel mode of context-dependent histone binding behavior points to the existence of an additional, so far unknown, layer of the histone code, which is based on the combination of defined single marks. The PI proposes to perform a detailed analysis of histone-binding characteristics of the EDM2-type PHD finger domain. Besides biochemical experiments to understand how this type of ?histone reader? module distinguishes between different combinations of histone marks, studies will also be performed to identify which plant genes bear such ?higher-level of histone code words? that can be read by EDM2. If successful, this study will substantially advance our basic understanding of epigenetics, which is the biological discipline focused on the function of histone marks and chemical modifications of DNA.

Broader Impacts-
In addition to its scientific significance, this project will have broader societal impacts. An important component of the proposed project is an involvement of undergraduate students, mainly from minority groups. The project will be linked to classes on plant biochemistry, biotechnology and molecular biology taught by the PI and the ongoing NSF-REU Plant Cell Biology program within the Center for Plant Cell Biology at UC-Riverside. In addition, the proposed project will provide a strong platform for training of a postdoctoral scholar and a graduate student and prepare them for careers as senior researchers in academia or industry. The goals of the America COMPETES Act of 2007 that emphasize the importance of comprehensive professional training and awareness of the responsible and ethical conduct of research are a top priority of this project. By regulating an immune receptor gene, EDM2 has an important role in mediating resistance of plants against diseases. Therefore, the significance of this study goes beyond its impact on basic epigenetics and will likely benefit society by allowing new solutions in crop disease protection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past two decades a new type of biological code critical for the proper function of genes has emerged. This new, so-called, histone or epigenetic code is manifested in certain chemical modifications of DNA-associated histone proteins. In contrast to the DNA code, which provides instructions for the synthesis of proteins, the histone code defines the activity states of genes and determines to what extent their genetic information is utilized. At this point numerous types of chemical modifications that can mark histone proteins at defined positions within their amino acid sequences have been identified. In some cases defined histone marks have been associated with enhanced or suppressed activity of genes. For example, the addition of an acetyl-tag to the 9th amino acid (a lysine) of the histone type H3 is often found in highly active genes, while methyl-tags at same position of histone H3 has been associated with suppressed genetic activity. It is also well established that certain proteins can “read” this histone code and dock to defined marks. When recruited to defined DNA regions by docking to their cognate histone marks, such histone binding proteins can alter activity levels of their respective target genes.

This project focuses on the characterization of a new type of histone binding protein. The EDM2 protein of the model plant Arabidopsis, originally identified as a critical regulator of plant immune responses, was found by the PI’s laboratory to specifically bind to histone H3 bearing certain combinations of three different chemical marks. These experiments were performed under in vitro conditions (in reaction tubes). Responsible for this unusual property is a part of EDM2 related to the known-PHD finger domain. While conventional PHD-finger domains have been found previously to dock to either single or double histone marks, it is remarkable that the atypical PHD-finger domain of EDM2 appears to be unable to bind to single or double marks, but is only able to “read” triple histone modifications. This novel mode of context-dependent histone binding behavior points to the existence of an additional, so far unknown, layer of the histone code, which is based on the combination of defined single marks.

 

The PI now performed further analyses of the histone-binding characteristics of EDM2 under in vivo-conditions (in intact plant cells). Using a method termed Chromatin-Immuno-Precipitiation, all sites in the Arabidopsis genome were mapped to which EDM2 docks. These new data combined with other data produced by the PIs lab as well as other researchers showed that EDM2 preferentially associates with combinations of histone marks that are typically found in actively expressed genes, as well as at sites where active genes are bordered by mobile genetic elements (aka transposons). The latter observation is very interesting. Being mobile genetic elements, transposons appear to “transplant” EDM2 docking sites by moving to new sites in the genome. New results from the PIs lab now indicate that such transposon-mediated dispersal of EDM2 target sites in plant genomes is an important mechanism for the evolution of plant immunity. Movement of transposons has equipped multiple immune receptor genes with a new EDM2-dependent regulatory mechanism, allowing the activity of these genes to be fine-tuned during plant immune responses. Malfunction of EDM2 (e.g. by mutation) can leave plants unprotected against diseases. The PI’s lab further identified additional proteins that cooperate with EDM2 in interpreting the histone code and in regulating plant immune receptor genes.

 

This study advanced our basic understanding of epigenetics, which is the biological discipline focused on the function of histone marks and chemical modifications of DNA. Its main intellectual merit lays its potential to provide a foundation for the understanding of higher-level epigenetic codes and to establish interesting previously unknown connections between epigenetics and the plant immune system.

In addition to its scientific significance this project has broader societal impacts. An important component of the proposed project has been major involvement of undergraduate and graduate students, some from minority groups. The project has also been linked to classes on plant biochemistry, biotechnology and molecular biology taught by the PI and the ongoing NSF-REU Plant Cell Biology program within the Center for Plant Cell Biology at UC-Riverside. In addition, the proposed project has provided a platform for training of a postdoctoral scholar and prepared her for careers as a senior researcher in academia or industry. By regulating immune receptor genes, EDM2 has an important role in mediating resistance of plants against diseases. Therefore, the significance of this study goes beyond its impact on basic epigenetics and will potentially benefit society by allowing new solutions in crop disease protection.
